Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I scanned the pool, eyes darting between the sunbathers and the kids splashing in the shallow end. It was Jamie, my best friend, and her voice trembled when I answered. “Can you talk? I really need you right now,” she whispered, barely holding back tears. I knew what she needed—someone to listen, to reassure her, to be the friend I always promised I’d be. But as she started pouring her heart out about her fight with Mark, I caught sight of a group of kids slipping under the rope into the shallow area, unsupervised. My training screamed at me: enforce the rules, keep everyone safe, don’t let your guard down. But Jamie’s voice in my ear was desperate, raw, and I could almost feel her pain. I gripped the phone tighter, torn between the duty to my friend and the responsibility to the swimmers. My heart pounded as I stood at the edge of the pool, caught between two worlds, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed from me in this moment.
